author: Quotidiano Nazionale
title: Allarme di Usa e Cina:: "Attesi raid più letali sul suolo ucraino". Cnn nel mirino di Mosca
text:
La Russia si sente minacciata dagli attacchi aerei e dalle invasioni ucraine. Crescono i timori di nuovi bombardamenti mentre la libertà di stampa è messa sotto accusa.
Non è solo l’invasione delle truppe ucraine nella regione di Kursk a far sentire vulnerabile la Russia. Gli attacchi dal cielo, con droni e missili, continuano a colpire infrastrutture civili e militari della Federazione, come successo nel porto di Kavkaz, vicino alla Crimea, dove un traghetto con a bordo decine di autocisterne cariche di carburante è stato bombardato ed è colato a picco. Mentre il presidente Vladimir Putin (foto) accusa Kiev di avere cercato di colpire anche la centrale nucleare di Kursk. Ma in un’Ucraina che si appresta a celebrare, il 24 agosto, il 33esimo anniversario dell’indipendenza, crescono i timori di una possibile intensificazione dei bombardamenti russi. L’ambasciata Usa e quella cinese hanno lanciato ieri un avvertimento ai loro connazionali presenti nel Paese perché si tengano pronti a mettersi al riparo in caso di allarmi aerei. La sede diplomatica americana ha precisato che l’allerta si riferisce ai "prossimi giorni e per tutto il fine settimana". Intanto la Russia di Vladimir Putin torna a prendere di mira la libertà di stampa. Dopo gli inviati Rai Stefania Battistini e Simone Traini, i servizi di sicurezza russi hanno annunciato un procedimento penale contro altri tre giornalisti: il corrispondente della Cnn Nick Paton Walsh e le reporter ucraine Olesya Borovik e Diana Butsko. L’accusa è "attraversamento illegale della frontiera", ovvero essere entrati in territorio russo senza il permesso di Mosca. Un’imputazione che prevede fino a cinque anni di reclusione.

author: Berguedà
title: El Govern es mostra disposat a contribuir en la recuperació de la planta de biomassa de la Valldan
text: La Mancomunitat de Municipis Berguedans per la Biomassa continua refent-se del cop de l'incendi a la planta de biomassa al Polígon Industrial de la Valldan. Expectants respecte del treball de peritatge forense que es continua desenvolupant a les restes de la central, avui l'ens, i els alcaldes i alcaldesses dels municipis que en formen part, han rebut la visita de la delegada del Govern a la Catalunya Central, Elia Tortolero, evidenciant la mà estesa de la Generalitat a l'hora de contribuir en la recuperació d'aquesta instal·lació. Tal com ha compartit davant els mitjans l'alcalde de Berga, Ivan Sànchez, el govern ha ratificat avui la predisposició manifestada el mateix dia dels fets per part del president de la Generalitat, Salvador Illa, a través d'una trucada. Gest que també van reproduir la consellera d'Interior i Seguretat Pública, Núria Parlon, i el conseller d'Agricultura, Ramaderia, Pesca i Alimentació, Òscar Ordeig. Serà precisament aquest darrer a través del qual la Mancomunitat haurà d'arribar a enteses, per la implicació respecte de la gestió forestal. La — Delegació del Govern a la Catalunya Central (@govcatcentral)[#delegada][@EliaTortolero]ha visitat l'[@Ajunt_Olvan]i els terrenys del polígon industrial amb l'alcalde[@Sebas_Olvan]. També ha visitat les instal·lacions de la Mancomunitat de Municipis Berguedans per a la Biomassa, juntament amb diversos representants municipals.[pic.twitter.com/ST4cmsGlkn][October 3, 2024] És justament el valor d'una explotació dels boscos complint uns criteris de sostenibilitat i apostant per l'economia circular com ho fa el projecte de la Mancomunitat el que atrau més el Govern i el convida a sumar esforços. Així ho ha assenyalat el president de l'organisme, Moisès Masanas, que ha precisat que, primerament, hi ha d'haver una resolució dels pèrits. "El Govern no farà res si no sabem què diuen les asseguradores", ha evidenciat. En tot cas, la Mancomunitat ha de fer a la vegada un exercici de reflexió intern, també a partir de la resposta de les assegurances i les primeres conclusions sobre els fets succeïts. En paral·lel, l'activitat de l'entitat es mantindrà en la resta de les àrees de treball, que segons el president, tenen a veure precisament en l'explotació i gestió forestal. "La Mancomunitat té diverses potes, i tot i que la de la planta és la més visual no és la que donava més feina", ha assegurat Masanas, que avança que ara optaran per vendre més matèria a la indústria. D'altra banda, respecte d'una eventual recuperació de la central, Moisès Masanas ha detallat que també hauran de parlar-ne al respecte amb les sis empreses a les quals prestaven servei -cinc amb aigua calenta i una amb oli tèrmic-, sobre les quals ha asseverat que és prioritari per l'organisme vetllar pel seu subministrament després de l'incendi. Sigui com sigui, el president referma que al Polígon de la Valldan "ja hi ha tota l'estructura muntada", cosa que pesarà a favor de cara a tornar a engegar el projecte. Això sí, deixant clar que la Mancomunitat, per si sola, "no té múscul per poder-ho refer".

author: archyworldyscom
title: New tests that support the possibility of life on Mars!
text:
Unveiling Mars’ Watery Past: A New Perspective For many years, scientists studying Mars have suspected the presence of water on the planet, a theory supported by images captured by NASA’s “Mariner 9” mission in the 1970s, which revealed dry channels. Despite this, debates have persisted regarding the nature and longevity of this water.
While some climate models suggest that any surface water on Mars was quickly frozen under ice caps, recent findings published in Science Advances on January 15 offer a contrasting narrative.
Images from NASA’s Curiosity rover have uncovered formations known as “wave ripples,” resembling small hills found at the bottom of lakes on Earth. This discovery suggests that liquid water once flowed on Mars’ surface,exposed too the atmosphere.
These intriguing formations were discovered in a basin within Gale Crater , an area explored by the Curiosity rover as August 2012.
“Wave ripples form exclusively under open water influenced by wind,” explains Claire M. de Leeuw, a sedimentologist at Caltech and lead author of the study.
By examining the height and spacing of these ripples, scientists estimated the size of the ancient lake. The ripples, standing about 6 mm tall and spaced 4 to 5 cm apart, indicate they formed in shallow lakes no deeper than two meters.
These dry lake beds are estimated to be around 3.7 billion years old, suggesting Mars once had a dense, warm atmosphere capable of sustaining liquid water for extended periods, longer than previously believed.
This revelation has significant implications, as de Leeuw notes: “Increased evidence of liquid water raises the possibility that Mars could have supported microbial life in it’s past.”
Thus, the potential for life to have developed on Mars may have been greater than once thought.
Over billions of years, Mars lost much of its atmosphere and surface water. Scientists attribute this to the planet’s loss of its magnetic field, leaving it vulnerable to solar radiation. The intense solar wind stripped away much of the Martian atmosphere, causing carbon dioxide and water to evaporate into space, resulting in the icy desert landscape we see today.
source: Live Science
markdown
New Tests That Support the Possibility of Life on Mars
The age-old question of whether humans are alone in the universe has long captured the creativity of scientists and dreamers alike. In recent years, advancements in space technology and research have brought us closer to answering this profound question, especially through new tests and findings on Mars. This article delves into the intriguing discoveries that bolster the possibility of life on the Red Planet, incorporating cutting-edge research and scientific insights.
Groundbreaking Discoveries from Perseverance Rover
NASA's Perseverance rover, which landed on Mars in February 2021, has been at the forefront of scientific exploration. Equipped with state-of-the-art tools, the rover has conducted several experiments that hint at the potential for life on Mars.
Subsurface Exploration and Sample Collection
One of the key areas of interest has been the exploration of Mars' subsurface.Perseverance is equipped with a drill capable of collecting rock samples from depths where the chances of preserving signs of ancient life are higher. These samples, if they contain organic molecules, could provide critical information about the planet's habitability.
Sample Analysis : Once returned to Earth, these samples will undergo rigorous testing using advanced laboratories capable of detecting traces of past microbial life.
Technological Innovation : The rover’s drill and other instruments demonstrate how technology continues to push the boundaries of what is absolutely possible in extraterrestrial exploration.
Detection of Organic Material
Perseverance has detected organic molecules in Martian rock samples.While the presence of organic material does not directly indicate life, as they can also be formed through abiotic processes, it does suggest that the conditions for life as we know it might exist.
Analytical Chemistry : Instruments like SHERLOC (Scanning Habitable Environments with Raman & luminescence for Organics & Chemicals) have identified these compounds.
Implications : Discovering organic molecules provides a fertile ground for the inquiry into whether Mars hosted life in its distant past.
Insights from Viking and Curiosity Missions
Before Perseverance, Viking and curiosity missions provided foundational data on Martian geology and surface conditions, both critical for assessing habitability.
Viking Landers' Enzymatic Tests
The Viking missions in the 1970s conducted experiments to detect microbial life by introducing nutrient-rich substances to Martian soil. Even tho results were inconclusive, they provided invaluable insights into Martian atmospheric and soil composition.
Results Overview :
- Gaps and Conflicts : Some tests suggested chemical activity, while others did not.
- Continued Interest : These conflicting results have paved the way for renewed scrutiny and advanced methodologies in current missions.
Curiosity Rover's Insights
Launched in 2011, NASA’s Curiosity rover has extensively analyzed the Gale Crater, revealing complex organic molecules and fluctuating methane levels in the atmosphere.
Methane Spikes : The detection of methane, a gas often produced by biological processes on Earth, poses intriguing questions. Though geological processes might also account for it, the seasonal variability urges further investigation.
Clay Minerals Finding : Such minerals form in the presence of water, indicating that ancient Mars had environments capable of supporting life.
Recent Scientific Hypotheses
As new data emerges, scientific hypotheses evolve, offering fresh perspectives on the possibility of life on Mars.
Hydrothermal Vent Theory
Recent studies speculate that Mars might harbor subsurface hydrothermal vents, akin to those on Earth which support diverse ecosystems.
Comparative Geology : These vents on Earth are teeming with life due to heat and minerals from the planet’s interior, suggesting similar environments on Mars could have once supported hypothetical Martian lifeforms.
Research Focus : Advanced imaging technology is being directed towards identifying regions on Mars that might host such subsurface features.
Cryo-Preserved Microbes
Scientists also explore the potential for cryo-preserved microbes within Mars' permafrost, analogous to extremophiles found in Earth's icy regions like Antarctica.
Extremophiles Insight : These organisms demonstrate survival in extreme conditions, raising the possibility that life on Mars, if it ever existed, could survive in a dormant state.
The Role of International Collaborations
International space agencies are increasingly collaborating to advance Mars exploration.
European Mars Trace gas Orbiter (TGO)
Launched in collaboration with Russia's Roscosmos,the ESA's TGO is helping to measure trace gases,particularly methane,in the Martian atmosphere.
Data Synergy : Combining TGO’s data with that from Perseverance provides a more comprehensive understanding of atmospheric dynamics and potential biogenic sources of methane.
Future Missions: ExoMars and Beyond
Upcoming missions such as ESA’s Rosalind franklin rover and NASA’s artemis program continue to build on these findings.
Rosalind Franklin Rover : Targeting the Oxia Planum region,this mission aims to uncover signs of past life by drilling and analyzing subsurface samples.
Artemis Program : While focusing on returning humans to the moon, it underscores the technological advancements supporting broader space exploration goals, including Mars missions.
Benefits of Understanding Mars' Habitability
Exploring the potential for life on Mars offers numerous benefits to Earth and space sciences.
Advancements in Technological Solutions
The development of technologies for Mars exploration has co-opted various sectors, including automation, AI, and environmental monitoring.
Innovation in Robotics : Mars rovers train robots to perform complex tasks with autonomy, informing Earth-based applications.
New Frontiers in AI : The need to analyze vast amounts of data from space missions drives advancements in artificial intelligence, useful across multiple domains.
Readiness for Future Human Space Exploration
Understanding Mars' environment is crucial for future human missions, ensuring the safety and feasibility of long-duration space travel.
Life Support Systems : Insights into Martian resources, such as water ice, assist in designing enduring life support and in-situ resource utilization technologies.
Human Adaptation Studies : Studying how humans might live on Mars informs broader research on human adaptability in extreme environments.
The Economic Impacts
Mars exploration also fuels economic growth by driving investment in technology and infrastructure.
space Industry Growth
The burgeoning space industry has seen considerable investments, with Mars missions at the forefront.
Commercialization of Space : The success of Mars missions fosters new business opportunities in satellite services, space tourism, and beyond.
Public-Private Partnerships : Collaborations between government space agencies and private companies accelerate innovation and reduce costs.
Conclusion
The possibility of life on Mars continues to captivate the world's imagination, driven by continuous advancements in space exploration.As new tests and findings emerge, our understanding of the Red Planet evolves, shedding light on its past and potential for future habitability. This vibrant field of study not only pushes the boundaries of human knowledge but also inspires technological and economic advancements with profound implications for life on Earth.
With international collaboration and technological innovation at its core, the quest to uncover secrets of Mars presents a unique avenue for scientific discovery and adventure. Only time will tell what new revelations lie in wait, but the possibilities are as vast as the cosmos itself.
Key Discoveries
Importance
Organic molecules
Indicators of potential life-supporting conditions
Methane Detection
Suggests possible biological activity
Subsurface Drilling
Accesses well-preserved samples from early Mars

author: Destiny Wiggins
title: Homeless service center hands out blankets for cold weather
text:
ORLANDO, Fla. — Homeless shelters across Central Florida are working overtime to make sure those trying to escape the cold have a place to go to stay warm.
With shelters being at capacity, one local homeless shelter had another idea in mind.
What You Need To Know The Christian Service Center is distributing blankets as temperatures across Central Florida drop
The center handed out over 200 blankets Saturday morning
Executive director Eric Gray says an additional 400 blankets have been ordered A last-minute decision turned into an outpouring response from the community, with residents dropping off their own donations one at a time.
“For every 48 cents, I can buy a blanket that looks like this. It’s an emergency Mylar blanket,” said Eric Gray, Executive Director for the Christian Service Center .
With cold temperatures in Central Florida this weekend, Gray says those who are experiencing homelessness have limited options to stay warm.
“The shelters will open up when the temperature drops below 40 degrees for four or more hours, but the shelters are full,” said Gray.
Gray said no shelter blankets were available, as people that visited the center Friday night requested one.
That’s when Gray sprang into action, making a video asking the community for their help. Saturday morning, over 200 blankets were handed out one by one.
Gray says with a staff of 29 people, he decided to take on today’s job by himself. He says that’s what it’s all about, stepping in as a leader to meet the needs in the community.
“I had staff that were willing to come out today and I was like, no, this is a one-person job, it’s not a big deal,” he said.
The Christian Service Center has been around for 53 years. It’s this type of work, and day like today, that keeps Gray going.
“So I’m like on top of the world being here. This is the dream come true for people to do this type of work. It just doesn’t get any better than this,” he said.
Gray says cold temperatures are one of the several hardships those experiencing homeless go through. He says that’s why he does his best to be there as a helping hand.
The service center has placed an additional order of 400 blankets, which will arrive on Sunday.

author: Margaret Flavin
title: NewsBusters Shares the Worst Examples of Journalism in 2023 Including 'The Jihadist Journalism Award for Helping Hamas' Margaret Flavin
text: Each year, Newsbusters gathers examples of outrageous partisan virtue-signaling masquerading as “journalism” for their list of “awards” of the worst of the worst. This year, the leftist hacks in the media provided plenty of options to choose from. There was so much to choose from, in fact, that NewsBusters editors expanded their list and broke the Worst of 2023 into eight additional categories, including “The Craziest Analysis Award; The Damn Those Conservatives Award; The Joy of Hate Award for Joy Reid Rants; The Jihadist Journalism Award for Helping Hamas; The Damning Florida’s Dictator Award; The Praising and Protecting Old Joe Award; The Cursing the Conservative Court Award and the Celebrity Freak-Outs Award.” This year, The Jihadist Journalism Award for Helping Hamas went to CBS’s Imtiaz Tyab for his Hamas cheerleading and the implication that homicidal terrorists who murder babies and use rape as a tool of war are really just plucky little underdogs with a dream. Tyab told his audience, “You know, over the years, I’ve made frequent trips to Gaza and have spoken with several Hamas leaders, and, you know, they know their military capabilities are no match for Israel’s enormous firepower. But what they lack in firepower, they make up for in ideology and sheer determination.” Watch: Without further ado here is the winner (followed by the top runners-up): His infamous line “But what [Hamas] lack in fire power, they make up for in ideology and sheer determination.” pic.twitter.com/rr7tJCt6bv — MRCTV (@mrctv) December 28, 2023 MRC’s Tim Graham joined Newsmax to discuss the awards. — Tim Graham (@TimJGraham) December 28, 2023 Runners-up for the award include New York Magazine’s Eric Levitz, Los Angeles Times investigative reporter Adam Elmahrek, MSNBC Host Ayman Mohyeldin, and correspondent Debora Patta for the following Quote: s: Watch MRC’s full montage of the runners-up below. Visit NewsBusters for additional award winners, including: WORST OF 2023: The Craziest Analysis Award WORST OF 2023: Damn Those Conservatives Award WORST OF 2023: The Joy of Hate Award for Joy Reid Rants Trending: BREAKING: Now There’s Proof! Brad Raffensperger Lied to President Trump When He Told Him in Jan 2021 Phone Call There Was No Fraud in 2020 Election

author: @PublimetroMX
title: Carlos Moreno logra el último trámite para viajar a Estado Unidos con México - Publimetro México
text:
Estamos a solo unas horas de que la Selección Mexicana vuelva a la actividad con su participación en la Nations League ante Canadá; sin embargo, en la semana previa a la disputa de la semifinal, el Tricolor tuvo un problema con su convocado, Carlos Moreno, quien no podía realizar el viaje a Estados Unidos por falta de documentación.
Este tema encendió las alarmas en el grupo debido a que por reglamento, en caso de poder presentarse a la cita, Javier Aguirre no podía llamar a un suplente, ya que no pertenecía a un caso de lesión. Por ello, a marchas forzadas, el staff de tuzos consiguió completar el último trámite que le faltaba al mexicano para poder sumarlo al grupo.
¿Cuál fue el problema de Carlos Moreno?
Es importante recordar que esto fue informado por el propio equipo del jugador, Pachuca, asegurando que todo se trató de un retraso en su trámite, algo que se resolvió a tiempo y tiene al portero viajando para reportar próximamente con El Vasco Aguirre.
“El Club de Futbol Pachuca a través del presente informa que respecto a la convocatoria a la Selección Nacional de México de nuestro guardameta Carlos Moreno, el miércoles 19 de marzo, se reportará y se incorporará a los trabajos del equipo dirigido por el D.T. Javier Aguirre en California, Estados Unidos, una vez que nuestro jugador ya ha podido concluir con el trámite de renovación de su visa a este país, el cual había sufrido un retraso por motivos administrativos ajenos al jugador y al Club Pachuca", se comentó en dicho comunicado.
Como ya mencionamos, la importancia de su presencia en la convocatoria pasa por la creación de un buen grupo y por la intención del estratega de que el jugador tome experiencia en citas internacionales, ya que si bien el titular será Ángel Malagón, el futuro de moreno apunta a ser recurrente en el Tri.
